Description: The year in which the Grand Prix race took place.
Marketing Relevance: Useful for analyzing trends over time, comparing different eras of F1, tracking historical performance, and understanding how regulations or technology changes impact competition.

Description: The official name of the circuit where the race was held.
Range/Values: Names of F1 circuits (e.g., 'Albert Park Grand Prix Circuit', 'Circuit de Monaco', 'Silverstone Circuit')
Marketing Relevance: Allows for analysis specific to track characteristics, helps target promotions for specific race events, and understands circuit-specific performance patterns for teams and drivers.

Description: Classification of the circuit (e.g., street circuit, permanent road course).
Marketing Relevance: Helps analyze performance based on track type, understand how different car setups perform, and tailor marketing content to highlight unique challenges.

Description: The city or geographical area where the circuit is located.
Marketing Relevance: Enables geo-targeted marketing campaigns, analysis of regional fan bases, understanding market potential in different locations, and logistics planning for sponsors.

Description: The full name of the driver participating in the race.
Range/Values: Names of Formula 1 drivers (e.g., 'Lewis Hamilton', 'Max Verstappen')
Marketing Relevance: Central to tracking driver performance, popularity, and marketability for endorsements. Used for fan engagement analysis and building narratives around individual competitors.

Description: The name of the constructor (team) the driver raced for.
Marketing Relevance: Essential for analyzing team performance, brand strength, fan loyalty, and evaluating sponsorship value and ROI associated with specific teams.

Description: The driver's starting position on the race grid, determined by qualifying.
Range/Values: 0 (Pit Lane), 1 up to the maximum number of cars starting the race
Marketing Relevance: Impacts pre-race predictions and analysis of race strategy. Higher grid slots generally correlate with better sponsor visibility at the start and potentially better race outcomes.

Description: The driver's official finishing position in the race.
Range/Values: 1 up to the number of classified finishers
Marketing Relevance: A primary measure of race success for drivers and teams. Used for rankings, performance tracking, and demonstrating competitiveness to fans and sponsors.

Description: Points awarded to the driver based on their finishing position.
Range/Values: Depends on the season's scoring system (e.g., 0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 18, 25)
Marketing Relevance: Key metric for championship standings and measuring season-long success. Directly impacts perceived value and success narrative for drivers and teams.

Description: Describes the driver's status at the end of the race.
Marketing Relevance: Provides insights into reliability and race incidents. Impacts brand perception (especially for engine/component suppliers) and helps analyze factors affecting race outcomes beyond pure pace.

Description: The position the driver achieved during the qualifying session(s).
Range/Values: 1 up to the number of drivers participating in qualifying
Marketing Relevance: Measures raw pace and single-lap performance. Used to analyze qualifying impact on race results, driver skill, and car competitiveness over one lap.

Description: A derived variable indicating the historical standing or perceived level of the constructor.
Marketing Relevance: Useful for segmenting teams for analysis, understanding competitive dynamics beyond current points, and potentially informing sponsorship value assessment based on brand equity.

Description: A derived indicator signifying whether the driver completed a sufficient portion of the race distance.
Marketing Relevance: Measures reliability and consistency. Finishing races is crucial for scoring points and impacts the perception of competence for both driver and team.

Description: A derived variable calculated as the difference between starting and finishing positions.
Range/Values: Positive integers (gained places), negative integers (lost places), 0 (no change)
Marketing Relevance: Highlights driver race craft, overtaking ability, and strategic effectiveness during the race. Positive changes create exciting narratives for fan engagement and media coverage.

Description: Could represent the cumulative number of races a driver or constructor has participated in.
Range/Values: 1 up to the maximum number of races entered by any entity
Marketing Relevance: Indicates experience level and longevity in the sport. Can be used in historical comparisons and adds context to performance analysis.

Description: A derived indicator signifying that the driver Did Not Finish the race.
Marketing Relevance: A key statistic for reliability analysis. High DNF rates can negatively impact brand image and are crucial for understanding consistency and championship potential.
